standfirst: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of Alexander Litvinenko, the former KGB spy poisoned with polonium in London in 2006, discusses a new inquiry into his death. She says the case could bring a "new era for relations between Russia and the west" – by revealing whether the Russian state supplied the radioactive material that killed her husband
headline: Litvinenko poisoning: inquiry could bring ‘new era for relations between Russia and the west’ says widow - video

standfirst: Politicians say a statue of Mahatma Gandhi will be unveiled in Parliament Square in London. In India to meet the country's new prime minister, they say the statue will be a 'monument of the friendship between Britain and India' and say his  lessons of peace between communities and non-violent protests are as relevant today as they were in his own time. Britain will put up a statue to the father of the world's largest democracy in 'the most prominent place that we can'
headline: George Osborne and William Hague announce new statue of Gandhi during visit to India – video

standfirst: An animation by the National Air Traffic Services (Nats), the UK air traffic control service, demonstrates the flight paths of the 2,000 to 3,000 aircraft that fly across the North Atlantic on a daily basis. This animation shows 2,524 flights that travelled between Canada, the US and Europe on a single day in August 2013
headline: Transatlantic flight paths of 2,524 planes on single day - video animation

standfirst: The prime minister says the security services need to listen to someone's phone and read their emails to stop terrorist plots; to do this the government relies on help from internet and telephone companies. The new laws he introduces strengthen their powers to do this, he says, and will also help in the fight against child abuse and other serious crimes. He says he 'will not  stand by' and watch foreign companies become less willing to share private information with the government
headline: David Cameron explains why new surveillance laws are needed and what they will allow – video

standfirst: In 1966, Harold Wilson assured MPs they would never be bugged. But most in Westminster believe his edict has been quietly circumvented many times over the years. Will new legal challenges shed light on decades of murky practice?
headline: Are spies flouting the 'Wilson doctrine' and bugging MPs?

standfirst:
The NSA whistleblower questions the need for emergency legislation in an exclusive Guardian interview, saying the move mirrors a hastily introduced US law in 2007, and asks whether it would 'really be so costly' to take time to debate the issue
